title: How Artificial Intelligence Is Transforming the Logistics and Freight Forwarding Industry
description: Discover how AI is revolutionising logistics and freight forwarding across Europe with smarter routes, automation, and data-driven efficiency.
imageAlt: Operations team oversees European freight flows using AI dashboards

children.text: In the fast-evolving world of European transport and logistics, artificial intelligence (AI) isn't a futuristic concept anymore-it's already shaping how goods move across borders. From forecasting shipment demand to automating customs procedures, AI is quietly becoming a must-have for freight forwarders aiming to stay competitive in a volatile market.

Driven by EU-wide digital initiatives-like the Digital Transport and Logistics Forum (DTLF) and the upcoming AI Act-the shift toward smarter, automated systems is accelerating. For logistics providers, this transformation isn't just about shaving off costs. It's about building resilience in the face of driver shortages, rising fuel prices, and increasingly complex environmental rules.

content.caption: Control tower staff rely on AI dashboards to orchestrate European freight flows.

content.text: The Role of AI in Modern Logistics

children.text: AI in logistics refers to the use of advanced machine learning models, big data analytics, and intelligent automation to enhance visibility, decision-making, and overall operational efficiency. For freight forwarders, this means fewer delays, better planning, and real-time insights across every leg of the supply chain.

content.text: Core AI Functions in Freight Forwarding

children.text: Helps anticipate weather disruptions, port delays, or seasonal demand spikes before they hit.
Speeds up customs documentation, invoice handling, and shipment tracking-cutting down on manual tasks.
AI analyses countless data points-from fuel costs to driver schedules-to find the most efficient, sustainable delivery routes.
The result? Faster, smarter, more flexible logistics operations-built for modern supply chain challenges.

content.caption: Dispatch planners review AI-generated routes that balance driver hours, cost and emissions.

content.text: Real-World AI Use Cases in Logistics

children.text: AI algorithms tap into live traffic data, port congestion alerts, weather forecasts, and more to plan optimal delivery routes.

DHL, for example, uses AI to cut mileage by up to 15% across European networks. These systems also integrate with Transport Management Systems (TMS) to ensure compliance with EU regulations and CO₂ monitoring requirements.
Benefit: Lower fuel consumption, fewer delays, and better on-time performance.
Connected trucks equipped with AI sensors constantly monitor engine temperature, brake wear, and other mechanical indicators.

Instead of waiting for breakdowns, the system flags potential failures before they happen-saving time and money. Some European fleets report up to 30% fewer roadside issues after adopting predictive maintenance.
AI doesn't just react to what happened last quarter. It pulls in data from retail trends, fuel markets, and even weather patterns to forecast shipping needs weeks-or months-in advance.
This helps forwarders avoid overbooking during seasonal peaks like Black Friday or pre-Christmas surges.
AI tools can read customs forms, cross-check tariff codes, and identify documentation errors automatically.
With the EU pushing toward a single digital customs platform by 2028, forwarders using AI now gain a competitive edge. Clearance times that once took hours can now be completed in minutes.
European logistics hubs are increasingly turning to AI-powered robotics for scanning, slotting, and picking.
DB Schenker's warehouse in Dortmund uses machine learning to assign shelf space based on how fast each product moves. This has improved space efficiency by over 25%.

content.text: Why Freight Forwarders Are Adopting AI

children.text: By optimising routes, loads, and warehouse workflows, AI helps eliminate waste and maximise efficiency.
According to McKinsey, AI could reduce logistics costs across Europe by up to 15% by 2030.
AI enables logistics managers to see every container, shipment, and truck in real time.
If there's a delay or issue-say, weather in Calais or a port strike in Hamburg-they can act before customers even notice.
AI chatbots now handle multilingual support queries, while real-time tracking systems keep customers updated on shipments 24/7.
That means fewer calls, fewer emails, and faster resolutions.
Optimised planning doesn't just save money-it reduces emissions.

AI helps cut fuel usage, identify opportunities for modal shift (like from road to rail), and track Scope 3 emissions more accurately-key for companies preparing for the EU's CSRD reporting requirements.

content.caption: Planner uses predictive analytics to align transport decisions with sustainability targets.

content.text: Challenges and Barriers to AI Adoption

children.text: Despite the clear benefits, the road to AI adoption isn't without bumps-especially for small and mid-sized operators.
AI systems require investment in cloud tools, sensors, and employee training.
Many SMEs still rely on older platforms that lack the flexibility needed for modern AI integration.
Supply chains often involve multiple players-carriers, customs brokers, ports-and each uses different systems.
Getting those data streams to talk to each other, securely and in line with GDPR, remains a major challenge.
As AI enters the workplace, job roles shift.

Drivers, warehouse workers, and planners must learn how to use these tools-and understand where human oversight is still vital. According to the European Commission, nearly half of all transport workers will require reskilling by 2030.
The EU's AI Act, expected to come into force by 2026, introduces stringent requirements around data use, transparency, and algorithmic accountability.
Firms using AI for customs decisions or transport routing must prove their systems are safe, unbiased, and auditable-or face penalties of up to €30 million.

content.text: What's Next: The Future of AI in Logistics

children.text: Driverless delivery trucks are no longer science fiction.
Pilots across Germany and the Netherlands are testing autonomous vehicles and drone delivery, with AI guiding navigation and decision-making.
AI-powered virtual models of real logistics networks-known as digital twins-are already being used at ports like Rotterdam.
They allow logistics managers to simulate delays, test different scenarios, and make smarter real-world decisions.
With the rollout of 5G, edge computing is enabling AI systems to process data directly on trucks, ships, or warehouses-rather than relying on the cloud.
This slashes latency and enables real-time problem-solving in high-speed environments.
AI will play a pivotal role in meeting the EU's "Fit for 55" targets by 2030.
Expect more integration between AI systems and carbon tracking tools, helping logistics providers not just report emissions-but actively reduce them.

content.alt: Digital twin of a pan-European logistics network visualises capacity and carbon scenarios
content.caption: Digital twin of a pan-European network lets teams test new capacity and carbon scenarios.

children.text: AI is no longer a luxury or a lab experiment. It's already embedded in how Europe's leading freight forwarders plan, optimise, and deliver.
For companies that haven't yet taken the leap, the message is simple: start small, choose one area-like routing or customs-and build from there.
The logistics firms that blend automation with human expertise will be the ones that stay ahead-faster, greener, and more connected than ever before.
